AttributeValuesData.AttributeValue: light gray, relatively thin with narrow, flat-topped or scaly ridges separated by narrow, shallow furrows; branches with large, scalelike plates

White Oak is a large forest tree reaching heights of 100' (in optimum setting) which is relatively common in the east-central and southeastern counties of Minnesota where it prefers deep, well-drained, acidic soils, usually sand or sandy loam. It has a deep root system and is very drought resistant, but is sensitive to flooding and sedimentation. It is slow growing, even in comparison to other oaks, and is among the longest-lived (500-600 years). Acorns of the white oak are edible and eaten by many kinds of birds and mammals. The wood is used for furniture, flooring, interior finishing, boat building, wine and whiskey casks. It is a difficult tree to transplant, production is difficult and growth is slow. Two white oaks are planted south of Darrell Krueger Library.
male slender, pendulous catkins 1-3" long on branchlets from previous year; female 1-3 on short peduncle from leaf axils on branchlets of the current year; wind pollinated early to late May
acorn which is an oblong nut 3/4-1" long with a scaly, dome-shaped or bowl-shaped cup with raised bumpy scales at the base covering 25-50% of the nut; matures in mid-August to late September
alternate, simple, oblong with rounded lobes and deep sinuses, dark green upper surface with pale green lower
large, slow-growing forest tree, deep root system, very drought resistant, long living
full sun, cannot survive in prolonged shade
